docs.lead_paragraph: IF you've just landed from Mars and want to understand some of the biggest issues in American society today, read up on some of the recent lawsuits filed against Wal-Mart. In October, federal agents raided 60 Wal-Mart stores in 21 states to round up more than 250 illegal immigrants who were janitors for contractors for the retailer.

headline.main: Illegal Immigration: So Harmful and So Beneficial

docs.abstract: Daniel Akst column focuses on impact of illegal immigrant workers; notes affluent are major beneficiaries, while competition from immigrants holds down wages for working poor; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare beneficiaries will not be allowed to buy insurance to cover their share of prescription drug costs under the new Medicare bill to be signed on Monday by President Bush, the legislation says. Millions of Medicare beneficiaries have bought private insurance to fill gaps in Medicare. But a little-noticed provision of the legislation prohibits the sale of any Medigap policy that would help pay drug costs after Jan. 1, 2006, when the new Medicare drug benefit becomes available.

headline.main: New Medicare Plan For Drug Benefits Prohibits Insurance

docs.abstract: Medicare beneficiaries will not be allowed to buy Medigap insurance to cover their share of prescription drug costs under new Medicare bill waiting Pres Bush's signature; lawmakers barred insurance because they did not want duplication of new Medicare benefit and wanted to be sure beneficiaries would bear some of cost; people with existing Medigap policies that cover drugs will be able to renew them, but only if they opt out of new Medicare drug benefit (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Representative Richard A. Gephardt accused President Bush this week of condoning a culture of corporate greed, he cast his criticism in distinctly moral tones. ''We've lost ethics,'' he told voters at a pizzeria in Independence, Iowa. ''We've lost a sense of right and wrong.'' One day later, Gen. Wesley K. Clark told Democrats at a crowded synagogue in Florida that he would never allow Republicans to claim a monopoly on faith.

headline.main: Democrats Try to Regain Ground on Moral Issues

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential hopefuls focus on ethical issues, as they seek to distinguish themselves and steer debate by discussing values, trying to reclaim ground increasingly dominated by Republicans over last decade; some are addressing synagogues and churches as they try to broaden appeal to uncommitted churchgoing voters in Midwestern and Southern primaries; polls of religious voters cited; photos (M)

byline.original: By RACHEL L. SWARNS and DIANE CARDWELL; Rachel L. Swarns reported from Des Moines for this article; Diane Cardwell reported from New Hampshire

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 100 workers at the famed Oyster Bar went on strike yesterday, but at lunchtime it looked as if the walkout was hardly having an effect. The counters and tables of the famed restaurant in Grand Central Terminal were packed with patrons happily eating bluepoint, belon and cherrystone oysters. Meanwhile, many of the Oyster Bar's regular dishwashers, waiters and cooks picketed out front, handing out leaflets saying that the restaurant wanted to undermine their pensions and health insurance.

headline.main: Nearly 100 Workers Leave Oyster Bar for Picket Line Outside Grand Central

docs.abstract: Nearly 100 workers from Oyster Bar restaurant at Grand Central Terminal stage walkout to protest against restaurant's purported plans to lower starting wages and require new hires to pay $1,600 per year in health insurance premiums (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Since his sudden rise to House speaker in 1999, J. Dennis Hastert has rarely been mentioned in the same breath as Congressional powerbrokers of the past. Yet in the hours before dawn on Nov. 22, Mr. Hastert was working the House floor the way Lyndon B. Johnson once managed the Senate, using the force of personal persuasion to secure passage of a critical bill. Desperate to win a few Republican converts and avoid a humiliating rejection of the Medicare drug plan, Mr. Hastert, an imposing former wrestling coach, was literally leaning on recalcitrant lawmakers to win their support. He used his authority to place the House in suspended animation for almost three hours until he could prevail on a handful of members to drop their opposition to the measure.

headline.main: Fight to Pass Medicare Measure Raised House Speaker's Profile

docs.abstract: Key role played by House Speaker J Dennis Hastert in winning passage of Medicare drug plan is altering perception of him in Washington, where he had been widely seen as amiable, but almost invisible, sidekick to House Republican leader Tom DeLay; he used his authority to put House in suspended animation while he persuaded handful of members to drop their opposition to bill; forcefully asserted self on issue in which he has long-standing interest; Democrats are villifying him and his lieutenants for way vote was conducted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials at Westchester Medical Center say they may have to lay off as many as 200 employees in the coming weeks to help stem continuing losses at the county's premier hospital. The medical center would not give a precise number of positions to be eliminated, but the amount of money saved is expected to be about double what was saved with a round of layoffs in March, when 110 workers were let go. The new personnel cuts, which will touch every department, are to save $16.5 million in pay and benefits, whereas the March layoffs yielded $8 million in savings.

headline.main: Westchester Medical Center May Lay Off 200 Workers

docs.abstract: Westchester Medical Center announces it may lay off 200 employees in effort to save expected $16.5 million after earlier round of 110 layoffs cut $8 million in pay and benefits; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Life's Work column in the Job Market section on Nov. 23 described the consequences of the loss of a paycheck for a family. It cited the example of Janet Ray Kalson, who joined a strike against her employer, MFY Legal Services, in late October. The column attributed the strike to a loss of benefits like good health insurance and the right to family medical leave after MFY split off from a larger group, Legal Services of New York City. The column should have included a response from MFY Legal Services. It says that while there were changes in its benefit plan, it still offers good health insurance at no monthly cost to its employees. It also says it plans to offer medical leave, provided the union refrains from lobbying against financing for MFY, as it did in one case last spring.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Holding Down Drug Prices'' (editorial, Nov. 28), you call for more ambitious efforts to support comparative drug research to identify those agents that work best. There must also be concerns about the fact that F.D.A. approval for most new drugs is currently based on research demonstrating their safety and efficacy in young and middle-aged adults.

docs.lead_paragraph: By better educating doctors about the most effective pneumonia treatments, Intermountain Health Care, a network of 21 hospitals in Utah and Idaho, says it saves at least 70 lives a year. By giving the right drugs at discharge time to more people with congestive heart failure, Intermountain saves another 300 lives annually and prevents almost 600 additional hospital stays. But under Medicare, none of these good deeds go unpunished.

headline.main: Hospitals Say They're Penalized By Medicare for Improving Care

docs.abstract: Sixth article in series Re-examining Medicare on swelling vanguard of critics who say Medicare's payment system is fundamentally flawed; Medicare pays hospitals fixed sum to treat specific diagnosis or perform given procedure, regardless of quality of care they provide; hospitals that work to improve are are not paid extra, and poor care is frequently rewarded, because it creates need for more procedures and services; experts say Medicare legislation that Pres Bush is expected to sign does little to reverse financial disincentives to improving care; Medicare's top official Thomas A Scully agrees that payment system needs to be fixed; many experts say that rather than paying for more studies, as new Medicare bill does, Congress should start making significant changes to way doctors and hospitals are paid; Intermountain Health Care, network of 21 hospitals in Utah and Idaho, says it foregoes roughly $1 million a year in Medicare payments because it makes sure its doctors prescribe most effective antibiotic for pneumonia patients, for example, and thereby avoids complications that would call for more treatment; photos; graphs (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Walgreen Company said yesterday that it would not join any more insurance plans that force consumers to get 90-day prescription refills by mail, a practice that threatens sales at its 4,291 pharmacies. Many health plans require patients to get supplies of maintenance medications from mail-order pharmacies, the company said. ''If the patient chooses to refill it at a retail pharmacy,'' Walgreen said, ''the insurance company won't provide coverage.''
docs.abstract: Walgreen Co will not join any more insurance plans the force consumers to get 90-day prescription refills by mail, practice that threatens sales at its 4,291 pharmacies; existing agreements with health plans will be honored (S)
